'''The Tarnac Nine''' are a [[France|French]] group of nine alleged [[Anarchism|anarchist]] [[Sabotage|saboteurs]]: Mathieu Burnel, [[Julien Coupat]], Bertrand Deveaux, Manon Glibert, Gabrielle Hallez, Elsa Hauck, Yildune Lévy, Benjamin Rosoux and Aria Thomas.<ref name="guardian1">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/03/france-terrorism-tarnac-anarchists |title=Rural idyll or terrorist hub? The village that police say is a threat to the state |last=Chrisafis |first=Angelique |date=January 2, 2009 |website=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref name="monde1">{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2008/11/20/sabotages-a-la-sncf-les-neuf-de-tarnac_1120974_3224.html |title=Les neuf de Tarnac |last=Mandraud |first=Isabelle |last2=Monnot |first2=Caroline |date=November 20, 2008 |website=[[Le Monde]]}}</ref><ref name="notbored1">{{cite web |url=http://notbored.org/bye-bye.pdf |title=''Bye-Bye St. Eloi! Observations Concerning the Definitive Indictment Issued by the Public Prosecutor of the Republic in the So-called Tarnac Affair'' |last=Becker, Burnel, Coupat ''et al.'', a.k.a. The Tarnac Ten |date=June 8, 2015 |website=Not Bored!}}</ref><ref name="monde2">{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2009/03/25/ce-que-contient-le-dossier-d-instruction-de-l-affaire-tarnac_1172333_3224.html |title=Ce que contient le dossier d’instruction de l’affaire Tarnac |last=Mandraud |first=Isabelle |date=March 25, 2009 |website=Le Monde}}</ref>{{efn|"Bertrand Deveaux, 22, Elsa Hauck, 24, Aria Thomas, 27, Matthieu Burnel, 27, Gabrielle Hallez, 30, Manon Glibert, 25, Benjamin Rosoux, 30 and Yildune Lévy, 25 have all since regained their freedom, albeit under judicial supervision. Only Julien Coupat, 34, considered the leader, remains incarcerated." —Translated from the French at ''[[Le Monde]]'', March 25, 2009.<ref name="monde2" />}} They were arrested on November 11, 2008 in an operation carried out by French police throughout [[Paris]], [[Rouen]] and particularly [[Tarnac]], rural France. The operation resulted in twenty arrests, of whom eleven were released almost immediately afterward.<ref name="radphi">{{cite web |url=https://www.radicalphilosophy.com/wp-content/files_mf/rp154_commentary_waragainstpreterrorism_toscano.pdf |title=The war against pre-terrorism: The Tarnac 9 and ''The Coming Insurrection'' |last=Toscano |first=Alberto |date=March-April 2009 |website=[[Radical Philosophy]], No. 154}}</ref><ref name="undercover">{{cite web |url=http://undercoverresearch.net/2015/08/14/the-curious-case-of-the-uk-spycop-the-french-invisible-committee-and-the-fbi/ |title=The curious case of the UK spycop, the (French) ‘Invisible Committee’ and the FBI |last=Coburg |first=Tom |date=August 13, 2015 |website=Undercover Research}}</ref><ref name="lepoint">{{cite web |url=http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites-societe/2009-12-18/coupat-levy-rosoux-qui-sont-les-protagonistes-du-groupe-de-tarnac/920/0/406444 |title=Coupat, Lévy, Rosoux... : qui sont les protagonistes du groupe de Tarnac? |last=Martin |first=Cyriel |date=December 18, 2009 |website=[[Le Point]]}}</ref> The remaining nine who were held for questioning, and who on November 15 were variously listed as suspects and accused of [[Crime|crimes]], then became known as the Tarnac Nine.<ref name="monde1" /><ref name="monde2" /> One year later, Glibert's husband Christophe Becker was also arrested in Tarnac in connection with the matter; as a result, the group is also sometimes known as the '''Tarnac Ten'''.
The group were "''accused of 'criminal association for the purposes of [[Terrorism|terrorist]] activity' on the grounds that they were to have participated in the sabotage of overhead electrical lines on France's national railways.''"<ref name="insurrectionbook">{{cite book |last=The Invisible Committee |date=2009 |title=The Coming Insurrection |location=Los Angeles, CA|publisher=Semiotext(e)|isbn=9781584350804 }}</ref><ref name="insurrection">{{cite web |url=http://paycreate.com/thecominginsurrection/ |title=''The Coming Insurrection'' |last=The Invisible Committee |date=2007 |website= Paycreate}}</ref>{{efn|See the very beginning of the [[Portable Document Format|.pdf]] for this quote, or else see p. 5 of the print version. The quote derives from a brief foreword which was added to the English edition of ''[[The Coming Insurrection]]''. ''The Coming Insurrection'' is a 2007 French political tract (translated into English in 2009) which has been associated with the Tarnac Nine case.}} In late October and early November of 2008, horseshoe-shaped iron bars were used to obstruct power cables of the [[TGV]] railways at locations throughout France, resulting in delays for about 160 trains.<ref name="undercover" /><ref name="vice">{{cite web |url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/kw7gnz/vive-le-tarnac-nine-407-v17n4 |title=Vive Le Tarnac Nine! |last=Smith |first=Aaron Lake |date=April 2, 2010 |website=[[Vice (website)|Vice]]}}</ref>{{efn|"The youths were accused of having participated in a number of sabotage attacks against high-speed TGV train routes, involving the obstruction of the trains’ power cables with horseshoe-shaped iron bars, causing a series of delays affecting some 160 trains." (p. 2.)<ref name="radphi" />}} In particular, one instance of this occurred on November 7-8, 2008, in [[Dhuisy]], [[Seine-et-Marne]], near Paris.<ref name="notbored2">{{cite web |url=http://notbored.org/yildune.pdf |title=Interrogation of Yildune Lévy by Judge Jeanne Duyé |last=Duyé |first=Jeanne |last2=Lévy |first2=Yildune |date=January 23, 2014 |website=Not Bored!}}</ref><ref name="monde3">{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article_interactif/2009/05/25/tarnac-le-point-sur-un-dossier-aux-zones-d-ombre-troublantes_1195503_3224.html |title=Tarnac, le point sur un dossier aux zones d'ombre troublantes |date=May 5, 2009 |website=Le Monde}}</ref>{{efn|"''Judge'' (Duyé): For his part, Julien Coupat declared in an explicit way when he responded to the questions of the examining magistrate that he wasn’t only at Seine-en-Marne during the night of 7 to 8 November 2008, but also that he was in your company. ''Response'' (Lévy): Yes, yes, I was indeed with him." (pp. 1-2.)<ref name="notbored2" />}} On the same night, Coupat and his partner Lévy were driving in the area, under police surveillance. Three days later, the arrests were made. On April 12, 2018, following a long and complex [[legal case]], the group were [[Acquittal|acquitted]] of the most serious [[Criminal charge|charges]] brought against them, including sabotage and [[conspiracy]], with some members being convicted on lesser charges.<ref name="guardian2">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/apr/13/tarnac-nine-leftwing-anarchist-terror-cell-fiction-france |title=Leftwing 'anarchist terror cell' is fiction, French judges rule |last=Chrisafis |first=Angelique |website=The Guardian |date=April 13, 2018}}</ref><ref name="inter">{{cite web |url=https://www.franceinter.fr/justice/sabotage-d-une-ligne-sncf-relaxe-pour-les-principaux-militants-du-groupe-de-tarnac |title=Sabotage d'une ligne SNCF : relaxe pour les principaux militants du groupe de Tarnac |website=[[France Inter]] |date=April 12, 2018}}</ref>
==Background and Tarnac==
The original group of nine consists of five women and four men, aged from 22 through 34 at the time of the arrests<ref name="monde1" /><ref name="monde2" />, who are generally well-educated. Coupat was a former graduate student and is a political writer, having contributed to a philosophical journal called ''[[Tiqqun]]''. Coupat's partner, Lévy, is an [[Archaeology|archaeologist]]. Others have been described as "a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] sitcom actor (Thomas), a distinguished [[Clarinet|clarinettist]] (Glibert), a student [[Nursing|nurse]] (Hallez, an ex-partner of Coupat's) and Benjamin Rosoux, an [[University of Edinburgh|Edinburgh University]] graduate who runs the (Tarnac's) grocer's shop and its adjoining bar-restaurant." At the time of the arrests, Deveaux and Hauck were also described as beginning graduate students in [[Sociology|sociology]] and [[English studies|English]], respectively.<ref name="guardian1" /><ref name="monde1" />
The nine were part of a larger group of like-minded, [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] young people who sought to relocate to a rural area in order to [[Simple living|live simply]] and [[Commune|communally]], shunning [[Consumerism|consumerism]].<ref name="guardian1" /><ref name="monde1" /> Consequently, they scouted locations and settled on Tarnac<ref name="monde1" /><ref name="radphi" />, both for its rural setting and also for the similar political orientation of the local residents: in [[Limousin]], Tarnac is part of an area of France which has a long history with [[Communism|communism]] and the [[French Resistance]] of [[World War II]], having successfully avoided [[Nazi Germany|German]] occupation.<ref name="vice" />{{efn|"In Tarnac (a village proud of its role in the Resistance, and represented by a communist mayor for four decades) a committee of support was set up, conveying a virtually unanimous show of solidarity of the villagers with those arrested." (p. 2.)<ref name="radphi" />}} Upon moving in, the group began operating a disused shop and bar, and began community initiatives such as a film club and food delivery services for elderly locals. The newcomers were generally well-liked by their neighbors.<ref name="vice" />{{efn|"Across the hill from the farm where Coupat was arrested, Thierry Letellier, the independent mayor of the neighbouring village, tended his sheep farm. He said: "They were my neighbours, helping me on the farm and selling my meat at the shop. They were kind, intelligent and spoke several languages. They were politicised, on the left and clearly anti-capitalist like lots of people here, but they were people active in community life who wanted to change society at a local level first."<ref name="guardian1" />}} On the other hand, authorities have rejected this positive image of the group, instead describing them as an anarchist [[Clandestine cell system|terrorist cell]] who sought a rural location as a base of operations and who shunned [[Mobile phone|cell phones]] in order to avoid detection by authorities.<ref name="monde1" />{{efn|"That many of the Tarnac group didn’t use cell phones only aroused police suspicion further, a fact the French government later menacingly ascribed to their need to avoid detection."<ref name="vice" />}}
==Legal Case==
From the time of the arrests until 2018, the group had been involved in complex legal proceedings in which the members faced various criminal charges related to terrorism, sabotage, conspiracy, and refusal to submit to [[DNA profiling|biological sampling]].<ref name="monde3" /><ref name="notbored3">{{cite web |url=http://notbored.org/tarnac-ten.html |title=''Why we will no longer respect the judicial restraints placed upon us'' |last=Burnel, Coupat ''et al.'', a.k.a. The Tarnac Nine |date=December 4, 2009 |website=Not Bored!}}</ref>{{efn|"If they are fascinated with us, we are not fascinated with them -- whom our children, not without humor, now call the "thieves of toothbrushes," because every time they aim their [[9×19mm Parabellum|9mm]] guns at us, they swipe all the toothbrushes for their precious DNA experts."<ref name="notbored3" />}} Four of the nine were released shortly after the arrests; Glibert, Hallez and Rosoux were later released on December 2, 2008, and Lévy was released on January 16, 2009. Coupat, who was presumed by the prosecution to be the group's leader, was released on May 28, 2009.<ref name="monde1" /><ref name="lepoint" /> In late November 2009, a further arrest was made: Christophe Becker, husband of Glibert, was arrested in Tarnac on related suspicions, and released shortly thereafter.<ref name="notbored3" /><ref name="montagne">{{cite web |url=http://www.lamontagne.fr/tarnac/2009/11/24/tarnac-les-policiers-ont-braque-un-enfant-de-quatre-ans_132167.html |title=Tarnac: "Les policiers ont braqué un enfant de quatre ans" |last=Nicolas |first=Mickaël |date=November 24, 2009 |website=[[La Montagne (newspaper)]]}}</ref>{{efn|"In the dawn hours of November 27, 2009, the French antiterror police descended into Tarnac once again to arrest a new suspect for the case, a man in his 30s named Christophe, whom the police believed to be close with the Tarnac Nine. Enraged by the arrest, the Tarnac Nine went on the offensive and wrote an acerbic letter to their judges that was published in ''Le Monde'' on December 3, titled ''Why We Will No Longer Respect the Judicial Restraints Placed Upon Us''."<ref name="vice" />}}{{efn|"Jérémie Assous is one of the defense lawyers for the Tarnac Nine. Manon Glibert, one of those indicted in the case, asked Assous to ensure the defense of Christophe Becker, her husband, arrested this morning in Tarnac. Becker will not be able to see his lawyer until the end of a 72-hour custody." —Translated from the French at [[La Montagne (newspaper)|''La Montagne'']], November 24, 2009.}}{{efn|French news media report an initial date for Becker's custody of November 24 (2009), while ''Vice'' and ''Not Bored!'' report an "arrest" date of November 27. The three-day interval appears to reflect French booking procedures per ''La Montagne'', with the true initial date of physical detention (if not legal arrest) being November 24.}} In response, and in defiance of the judicial supervision with which they were ordered to comply, the nine met and jointly wrote a letter, published in ''Le Monde'' in early December: ''Why we will no longer respect the judicial restraints placed upon us.''<ref name="vice" /><ref name="notbored3" />{{efn|''Vice'' reports a publication date of December 3 (2009), while ''Not Bored!'' gives December 4.}} The group's judicial supervision orders were lifted on December 18, 2009<ref name="lepoint" /><ref name="vice" /><ref name="notbored4">{{cite web |url=http://notbored.org/lifted.html |title=Judicial supervision of Julien Coupat lightened |date=December 18, 2009 |website=Not Bored!}}</ref>, and due to the new arrest, the group are sometimes instead described as ''the Tarnac Ten''.
The prosecution's case was based upon police surveillance of the group, particularly the above proximity of Coupat and Lévy to a site where sabotage occurred. Further, the group generally (and Coupat specifically) were suspected of being possible members of [[The Invisible Committee|the Invisible Committee]], an anonymous author (or authors) who wrote ''[[The Coming Insurrection]]'', an [[Anti-capitalism|anti-capitalist]], anarchist tract originally published in 2007 which admonishes its readers to ''form communes'' and disrupt [[Infrastructure|infrastructure]], reminiscent of the politics and activities which the group were actually engaged in, and also of the specific crimes with which they were accused.<ref name="undercover" />{{efn|"French police say Coupat was the author of an anonymous tract against capitalism and modern society, ''The Coming Insurrection''."<ref name="guardian1" />}} In particular, according to the prosecution, one passage of the book seems to directly anticipate the rail sabotage:
{{Quote|text=Information and energy circulate via wire networks, fibers and channels, and these can be attacked. Nowadays sabotaging the social machine with any real effect involves reappropriating and reinventing the ways of interrupting its networks. '''How can a TGV line or an electrical network be rendered useless?''' How does one find the weak points in computer networks, or scramble radio waves and fill screens with white noise? |title= The Invisible Committee, ''The Coming Insurrection'', p. 112.<ref name="radphi" /><ref name="insurrectionbook" /><ref name="insurrection" />}}
Over time, the prosecution's case weakened. As the case progressed, it was asserted that the method of sabotage employed could not have caused injuries, but merely disruption.{{efn|"An SNCF maintenance technician stated that the malicious device 'could not in any way have caused an accident resulting in bodily harm'." —Translated from the French at ''Le Monde'', March 25, 2009.<ref name="monde2" />}}{{efn|"The sabotage was done with the purpose of stopping the trains and couldn’t have resulted in any injuries or derailments."<ref name="vice" />}} Thierry Fragnoli, a [[Magistrate|magistrate]] originally assigned to the case, [[Judicial disqualification|recused]] himself in April 2012.<ref name="monde4">{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2012/04/04/affaire-de-tarnac-le-juge-fragnoli-obtient-son-dessaisissement_1680169_3224.html |title=le juge Fragnoli obtient son dessaisissement |last=Borredon |first=Laurent |date=April 2, 2012 |website=Le Monde}}</ref>{{efn|"Thierry Fragnoli, whose lack of impartiality forced him to recuse himself from the case in 2012 after an article was published in ''Le Canard enchaîné''." (footnote, p. 6.)<ref name="notbored1" />}} In addition to being released from jail and having their judicial supervision lifted (despite the seriousness of the accusations), on August 7, 2015, magistrate Jeanne Duyé ordered that the specifically ''terrorist'' related charges against the group be dropped,<ref name="yahoo">{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/french-anarchist-cell-cleared-terror-charges-over-rail-185727585.html |title=French 'anarchist cell' cleared of terror charges over rail sabotage |last=Deviller |first=Sophie |date=August 8, 2015 |website=[[Yahoo]]}}</ref> a judgment which was upheld by the [[Court of Cassation (France)|French supreme court]].<ref name="monde5">{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/police-justice/article/2017/01/10/la-justice-ecarte-definitivement-la-qualification-terroriste-dans-l-affaire-de-tarnac_5060419_1653578.html |title=La justice écarte définitivement la qualification d'acte terroriste dans l'affaire Tarnac |website=Le Monde |date=January 10, 2017}}</ref><ref name=croix>{{cite web |url=https://www.la-croix.com/France/Justice/Derniere-etape-avant-proces-dans-laffaire-Tarnac-2017-01-10-1200815982 |title=Affaire Tarnac: La justice écarte définitivement la qualification d'acte terroriste |last=Thomasset |first=Flore |website=[[La Croix]] |date=January 10, 2017}}</ref> On April 12, 2018, the group were acquitted of the most serious remaining charges brought against them, particularly sabotage and conspiracy, while certain members were convicted on lesser charges with minimal or no sentences.<ref name="guardian2" /><ref name="inter" />
In response to the publicity of the arrests, several philosophers came to the support of the nine, including [[Giorgio Agamben]], [[Alberto Toscano]], [[Alain Badiou]], and [[Slavoj Žižek]].<ref name="vice" />{{efn|"Giorgio Agamben and Luc Boltanski wrote editorials decrying the disproportion and hysteria of this repressive operation. A petition was circulated by Eric Hazan, publisher and friend of Coupat, and signed by Badiou, Bensaïd, Butler, Rancière, Žižek and several others." (p. 2.)<ref name="radphi" />}} Further, several international "support committees", on behalf of the nine, "have sprung up across France and in the US, Spain, and Greece".<ref name="guardian1" />
==See also==
* [[Anarchism]] * ''[[The Coming Insurrection]]'' * [[Julien Coupat]] * [[The Invisible Committee]] * ''[[Tiqqun]]''
==External links==
* [http://notbored.org/tarnac.html ''Not Bored!''] ''Not Bored!'' is a [[Situationist International|Situationist]] periodical which maintains a page on its website of materials related to the Tarnac Nine case, typically translated from French into English.
* [http://www.lemonde.fr/affaire-tarnac/ ''Le Monde''] major French news organization ''Le Monde'' maintains an archive of its reporting on the Tarnac Nine.
* [https://www.radicalphilosophy.com/wp-content/files_mf/rp154_commentary_waragainstpreterrorism_toscano.pdf ''Radical Philosophy''] Alberto Toscano comments on the case of the Tarnac nine, and its relation to ''The Coming Insurrection'', etc.
* [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/libertycentral/2009/jan/28/human-rights-tarnac-nine ''Criminalising Dissent''] In a further piece at the Guardian, Toscano points out that the case of France's Tarnac Nine shows we are losing the political literacy to distinguish between sabotage and terrorism.
